revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-09 09:41:25.000000000', 'message': 'Add lower-constraints job to current development branch

The lower-constraints test was removed because of an issue where pip
could not correctly determine the required packages versions to install,
ending in an almost infinite loop that would end up in timeout, failure,
and general mayhem.
Recently the issue has been fixed and, if properly configured, the
lower-constraints test can provide good indication of which minimum
versions are required to support the current code.
This patch adds the test back to the current development branch, and it
runs only on master.
The lower-constraints file will stay in the future stable branches.

Change-Id: I53c027b72d560ce5f4f38368ee75d464d333835b
'}]
commit_message:
Add lower-constraints job to current development branch

The lower-constraints test was removed because of an issue where pip
could not correctly determine the required packages versions to install,
ending in an almost infinite loop that would end up in timeout, failure,
and general mayhem.
Recently the issue has been fixed and, if properly configured, the
lower-constraints test can provide good indication of which minimum
versions are required to support the current code.
This patch adds the test back to the current development branch, and it
runs only on master.
The lower-constraints file will stay in the future stable branches.

Change-Id: I53c027b72d560ce5f4f38368ee75d464d333835b

From what I see in the journal log and the related haproxy requests, sounds like the backend on port 8080 cannot be reached (resulting in 503) [1].
The rgw log [2] (which is in debug mode) shows that at some point there are networking issues.

```
2021-08-04T21:04:26.298+0000 7fb61262b700 -1 RGWWatcher::handle_error cookie 94891104038144 err (107) Transport endpoint is not connected
```

As far as I can see, cephadm  (which is in DEBUG mode), sees the RGW up & running, because the unit is still alive, but for haproxy there are no backends available, that's the reason all the requests are queued.

```
Aug 04 21:05:26 standalone.localdomain haproxy[112209]: Server ceph_rgw/standalone.ctlplane.localdomain is DOWN, reason: Layer7 timeout, check duration: 10001ms. 0 active and 0 backup servers left. 0 sessions active, 0 requeued, 0 remaining in queue.
Aug 04 21:05:26 standalone.localdomain haproxy[112209]: proxy ceph_rgw has no server available!
```

commit_message:
Bump Ceph container daemons to v6.0.4

The stable Ceph containers v16.2.5 are now released.
This change aligns the new tag with the latest released stable
content (which is v6.0.4 for the daemon images).

Change-Id: I50a683aaa7062f7f33d6de45758844c8523da7f2

commit_message:
Deprecate continue_node_clean() RPC API method

This spec propose to deprecate "continue_node_clean" RPC API
cast method and use instead new deploy interface method.

Change-Id: I57c820ceb9f28e4af37a4aca220c1097427cbc4e
Related-bug: #1688489

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2015-12-21 18:04:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

Interesting idea -- I can see the usefulness of this feature in many environments, though I suggest renaming it to be more inline with openstack's terminology.

Hoewver, I think the implementation of this is going to need to wait, and I'd like spec reviewers to focus their time on things we can achieve in the near-term. Any significant design work done on this feature, when features it depends on have not been implemented, seems premature at this point.

I am putting a -2 here to so that reviewers focus on other specs right now. Let's look at this again next cycle."}, {'account_id': 13719, 'date': '2015-12-24 09:00:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(8 comments)

Tang, Devananda,

Thanks for taking your time to review this patch.
Please find my replies in line.
Getting any feedback as earlier as possible is always good for all of
us, I believe.

In terms of (-2), I'm really afraid of a situation that non-core
reviewer also would walk off away from reviewing this spec even though
they could help core reviewer reduce work load.

Best regards,
Naohiro"}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2016-01-06 20:54:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi,

We recently reorganized the ironic-specs repository and now have a specs/not-implemented directory. Sorry for the inconvenience."}, {'account_id': 13719, 'date': '2016-01-13 05:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-01-13 05:57:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

commit_message:
Bare metal node N+1 redundancy

This proposes high availability/reliability feature to support Bare
Metal Node N+1 Redundancy based on `[RFE] Add volume connection
information into ironic db` and `[RFE] Enhance Power Interface
for Soft Power Off and Inject NMI`.

Partial-Bug: #1526234
Related-Bug: #1526231
Related-Bug: #1526226

Change-Id: I3776dd497e6b1d8cf4f7e59f8663d9d787c8d1f1

commit_message:
IPA telemetry

Proposes making IPA periodically reporting basic metrics
on running processes and ramdisk operating system itself,
then store this information in ironic DB for operator to
consume.

Story: 1709983
Change-Id: I32ba191071fda2426e00e6fee1f04c7ff40c7e69

subject: Add SAML 2 federation support
messages:
[{'account_id': 33694, 'date': '2021-08-13 13:31:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 33694, 'date': '2021-08-13 13:32:26.000000000', 'content': 'Set Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 33694, 'date': '2021-08-13 13:37:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 33694, 'date': '2021-08-16 09:40:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 33694, 'date': '2021-08-16 09:54:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 33694, 'date': '2021-08-16 12:36:01.000000000', 'content': 'Set Ready For Review'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2021-08-17 10:00:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Here is the patch I was thinking of that uses auth_mellon: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/755475. It got abandoned.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2021-08-17 10:03:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 32398, 'date': '2021-08-17 14:25:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)

All in all I really think that this whole federation feature should be based on a blueprint as there is a correct generic way to integrate it, that take care of both, OIDC and SAML2 while letting you as an operator a whole mix of many providers and providers type in the same time.

For instance, HAProxy configuration should be automatic and not rely on defaults as they should only activate when enable_keystone_federation AND keystone_federation_type (enum value such as (for now) OIDC or SAML2) variables are filled.

The proper OIDC or SAML2 configuration folder should be:
`/etc/kolla/config/keystone/federation/(oidc|saml2)/`

rather than `/etc/kolla/config/keystone/federation/attribute_maps` folders as this folder should also host certs additionally to the IDP and SP Metadata xml files.'}]

commit_message:
Add SAML 2 federation support

Adds support for configuring Keystone with mod_mellon
to support SAML 2 IdPs. This is an extension of the
existing OpenID support and uses a lot of the same
mechanisms.

This also renames the oidc attribute mapping variables
to make them generic, as all identity providers will
use the same mechanism for registering mappings.

Change-Id: I69869be87856b3fe9cb76a3214703f61af67ee22

If we can stop losing time, temper, resources in "useless" branches, that's all for the better.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2021-08-04 18:11:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2021-08-08 22:10:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-11 10:20:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

Let me please block this for just a tiny moment, until I have please answers to a few (stupid) questions...


What pushes tripleo, to test wallaby on centos 8/stream, AND later centos 9 simultanously? Same to Xena: what pushes tripleo community to run CI for it on both C8 stream AND C9? Why can't we only test on that we have available - centos 8/stream. Is there so tight connection for upstream so it becomes mandatory to run it on C9 to not break downstream on rhel 9?..

Finally, could we "detach" upstream from that mandatory too-much-future-looking base OS requirement instead of detaching it from the unified cadence model? And if we don't want to have stable/xena, could we afford not branching it within the unified cadence rules but not following the stable policy?'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2021-08-11 12:09:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2
> 
> Let me please block this for just a tiny moment, until I have please answers to a few (stupid) questions...
> 

thanks I have tried to reply inline 

> 
> What pushes tripleo, to test wallaby on centos 8/stream, AND later centos 9 simultanously? Same to Xena: what pushes tripleo community to run CI for it on both C8 stream AND C9? Why can't we only test on that we have available - centos 8/stream. Is there so tight connection for upstream so it becomes mandatory to run it on C9 to not break downstream on rhel 9?..
> 


on the tight connection - it depends, there is for wallaby because we our rh prod chain imports from upstream wallaby for OSP17

for xena d/stream is irrelevant in the same way as ussuri is irrelevant as we don't import that so isn't directly part of the osp production chain.

So I think you make a good point otherwise, i.e. we don't *have* to maintain both types of CI? We start with what we have so c8-stream then when it becomes available we move to the c9 stream without maintaining both. There will be some overlap for a brief period I guess but I think we can consider this point.


> Finally, could we "detach" upstream from that mandatory too-much-future-looking base OS requirement instead of detaching it from the unified cadence model? And if we don't want to have stable/xena, could we afford not branching it within the unified cadence rules but not following the stable policy?


I am not clear what you mean here. Do you mean, stay with the current release policy but choose not to create a X branch? I don't think this is an option, i.e. we are bound to create a branch, albeit 'up to 6 months late' since we are following cycle with intermediary.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-08-11 14:01:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> What pushes tripleo, to test wallaby on centos 8/stream, AND later centos 9 simultanously? Same to Xena: what pushes tripleo community to run CI for it on both C8 stream AND C9? Why can't we only test on that we have available - centos 8/stream. Is there so tight connection for upstream so it becomes mandatory to run it on C9 to not break downstream on rhel 9?..
> 
> Finally, could we "detach" upstream from that mandatory too-much-future-looking base OS requirement instead of detaching it from the unified cadence model? And if we don't want to have stable/xena, could we afford not branching it within the unified cadence rules but not following the stable policy?

The base OS is more important for tripleo than the rest of the services (except things like maybe nova because libvirt) due to close ties to the kernel.  For tripleo we still have dependencies on base OS provided things (podman/pacemaker/network-scripts) so it's not agnostic and cannot be as long as we depend on these tools.  We hit this with centos7/centos8 so we've already had these problems in the past which is why we'd like to reduce how long we have to carry the testing of each (e.g. 1 branch vs 3).  In testing c8/c9, there are less problems as we've seen that we can run the c8 containers on c9 but we hit issues around networking (looking at you NetworkManager) and containers (podman).  But there's no guarantee that we won't hit issues with c10 like we did with the c7/c8 transition which were far larger than what we've seen for c8 to c9.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-11 14:15:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

I think I have the answers now, so unblocking'}, {'account_id': 15993, 'date': '2021-08-13 00:20:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-08-16 13:51:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-08-16 21:23:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-08-17 14:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Moving TripleO repos to independent release model

As discussed in [1] this lays out the proposal to move tripleo
repos to independent release. Tried to address the points raised
in the discussion.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-June/thread.html#22959

Change-Id: I58bceea4920958e6009bb7193f7946217b0d1d2c

commit_message:
dnf: add metalink argument to custom dnf repository

As per [1] mandatory configuration option is either baseurl, mirrorlist
or metalink.

EPEL repos use metalink and it's impossible to configure them via DNF
custom repos functionality right now.

[1]: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/builtin/yum_repository_module.html#parameter-metalink

Change-Id: Ib267b648f011a7efa6440b6adf9ea8b9b5a0931f
(cherry picked from commit a48cc2498859f5949d304266d32ce3e620ad7f36)

subject: Allow overriding environment variables of horizon container
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-12-14 01:15:32.000000000', 'message': "Allow overriding environment variables of horizon container

Currently we use environment variables to determine enable dashboars,
but these variables are statically defined and can't be overridden.

This change introduces a new parameter to override the variables so

according to the services enabled.

Change-Id: I8ff3d76c59f4c24e6180681ce2bbc89b168b64bd
"}]
commit_message:
Allow overriding environment variables of horizon container

Currently we use environment variables to determine enable dashboars,
but these variables are statically defined and can't be overridden.

This change introduces a new parameter to override the variables so
that specific dashboards can be enabled or disabled explicitly
according to the services enabled.

Change-Id: I8ff3d76c59f4c24e6180681ce2bbc89b168b64bd

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-30 01:17:08.000000000', 'message': "Do no log output for async puppet tasks

Currently we don't disable log in wait task for wait tasks, we have
all outputs of puppet execution shown when async task is finished.
This causes huge length of line shown because all of the output are
compressed into one line by ansible.
We already have the subsequent task to show stdout/stderr output, thus
this outputs are not useful but just annoying.

Change-Id: Ie81ca5056777d2e3e56602000fc5d681b2abab85
"}]
commit_message:
Do no log output for async puppet tasks

Currently we don't disable log in wait task for wait tasks, we have
all outputs of puppet execution shown when async task is finished.
This causes huge length of line shown because all of the output are
compressed into one line by ansible.
We already have the subsequent task to show stdout/stderr output, thus
this outputs are not useful but just annoying.

Change-Id: Ie81ca5056777d2e3e56602000fc5d681b2abab85

Some openstack installations use characters that are not in \w, the
old regex, now moved to string2hash was more permissible, and
there's probably no reason the regex in pythondict2hash can't be
just as permissible.

Change-Id: I35b964d96e6a558f1a10daa2391a398db60ea800
"}]
commit_message:
Allow for a more permissible regex

Some openstack installations use characters that are not in \w, the
old regex, now moved to string2hash was more permissible, and
there's probably no reason the regex in pythondict2hash can't be
just as permissible.

Change-Id: I35b964d96e6a558f1a10daa2391a398db60ea800

[{'created': '2021-08-16 16:46:20.000000000', 'message': 'cinder_api: Export /var/log/httpd on the host

/var/log/httpd/cinder_wsgi_*.log inside the container are

folder:

  { "Type": "bind", "Source": "/var/log/containers/cinder", "Destination": "/var/log/cinder", "Driver": "", "Mode": "", "Options": [ "rbind" ], "RW": true, "Propagation": "rprivate" },

Change-Id: I1367fadb75d864dab39481500fdaa1173701cb42
'}]
commit_message:
cinder_api: Export /var/log/httpd on the host

/var/log/httpd/cinder_wsgi_*.log inside the container are
not exported on the host:

This is because it only bind mounts the cinder logs and not the httpd
folder:

  { "Type": "bind", "Source": "/var/log/containers/cinder", "Destination": "/var/log/cinder", "Driver": "", "Mode": "", "Options": [ "rbind" ], "RW": true, "Propagation": "rprivate" },

Let's do the same as cinder_api_cron which does export them

Closes-Bug: #1940127
Change-Id: I1367fadb75d864dab39481500fdaa1173701cb42

commit_message:
Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE

UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is old name and deprecated
This allows to use upper-constraints file as more
readable way instead of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=<lower-constraints file>.

Change-Id: I0de17288315d3d6358f627e28a920fb2f3aac10c

commit_message:
dnf: add metalink argument to custom dnf repository

As per [1] mandatory configuration option is either baseurl, mirrorlist
or metalink.

EPEL repos use metalink and it's impossible to configure them via DNF
custom repos functionality right now.

[1]: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/builtin/yum_repository_module.html#parameter-metalink

Change-Id: Ib267b648f011a7efa6440b6adf9ea8b9b5a0931f
(cherry picked from commit a48cc2498859f5949d304266d32ce3e620ad7f36)

commit_message:
Add port-resource-request-groups shim API ext

Add a new shim API extension definition called
port-resource-request-groups. This extension indicates that
Neutron supports the new format of resource_request, that allows
to request multiple groups of resources and traits from the same RP
subtree.

Related-Bug: #1922237
See-Also: https://review.opendev.org/785236
Change-Id: Idbfa3998930374b8de1e65d586ab54f85707c713

commit_message:
[doc] Add config reference guide

Masakari monitors are missing available configuration options
in its documentation which makes hard to configure them for users.

This patch adds automaticually generated reference about
available configuration options with their descriptions and defaults.

Change-Id: I2abc2afa6ae207c64186ab34b51a13c174cbf235

commit_message:
Add connection and status code check for tripleo get hash

Adds check that the response from delorean is 200 OK otherwise
error. Added test case to cover the new functionality.

Also removes the unnecessary gzip.decompress introduced by the
parent patch at [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-repos/+/804221/5#message-86528e2d861606e0516fa3f54cea64e2391f80e2

Change-Id: I6e26310c9b67fe42f65ca6ee3d55f88cf59275f8

commit_message:
Replace use of update.values parameter

Resolve the following RemovedIn20Warning warning:

  The update.values parameter will be removed in SQLAlchemy 2.0.  Please
  refer to the Update.values() method.

Change-Id: I426605aa8f4332fd0b7d9f6fa0e97d7e02c7cbdc
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Allow find to be called via rootwrap

Create a precise regex that matches the target find
commands executed by healthchecks for nova and cinder containers

Partial-bug: #1940068

Change-Id: I4e6d583ba597b75a67f0261a2f6885601e07edbb
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

subject: Use rootwrap facility for nova/cinder healthchecks
messages:
[{'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-16 11:37:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-16 11:38:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-16 11:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-17 07:43:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2021-08-17 08:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Do we know what user is actually used with that "podman healthcheck run"? I suspect it's the USER now, while the manual systemd unit was using "-u root" back then.

So I'm wondering if this "sudo" call is still useful at all, especially with the potential access right issues.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2021-08-17 09:23:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

After some testing (on a controller node, so not as extensive as it could be), it seems we can "just" remove the `sudo -u $puser ' from the command.

The history of that sudo:
- with older podman, there was no healthcheck support, so a dedicated systemd unit was generated, and it was using "podman exec -u root ...." in order to run the healthcheck
- newer podman has healthcheck support, and seems to run them as USER (cinder, nova, heat, ...)

The goal of the "sudo -u $puser" was to run the "find" as that USER, since it's the one owning the files, in order to prevent read access issues.


Since embedded healthchecks are running as USER already, there's no need to impersonate it anymore.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2021-08-17 09:53:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/804838 is probably a better way to address the issue.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-17 11:54:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

sudo can be removed instead'}]

commit_message:
Use rootwrap facility for nova/cinder healthchecks

Whenever there is ROOTWRAP specified for a service, attempt
to find its open sockets via its container-contained rootwrap
filter config.

Change-Id: I3900ce4d88116ee72713086dbc1b20d8b91fa45f
Closes-bug: #1940068
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/804702
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
virt: Add destroy_secrets kwarg to destroy and cleanup

This change adds a simple optional kwarg to the virt driver signature of
destroy and cleanup to allow for callers to control when secrets should
be removed.

Change-Id: I856268b371f7ba712b02189db3c927cd762a4dc3
(cherry picked from commit 1cc52fd2f22ec37194519e473c88260bf90a3c8c)

commit_message:
Support both frr 7.x and frr-8.0 concurrently

frr 7.x rpms use /usr/lib/frr/frr to start the FRR daemons.
frr 8.x rpms use /usr/libexec/frr/frrinit.sh

Let's support both for the time being.

Tested on a tripleo master environment with frr 8.x rpms.

Change-Id: Ie0aef47ca0900ad4ad8222ea0c4454a83e4b7c59

commit_message:
Set cephfs-nfs container PidsLimit to unlimited

By default, the ceph-nfs container has a default
PidsLimit set to 4096 threads. This is constraining,
since each exported share spins ~15 threads.

Followed same approach as ceph-ansible [0] for consistency,
and removed the limit altogether.

[0] https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/pull/6789/commits/aac0ba591a197640067077b32e6a45bfbf5dfdd7

Closes-Bug: #1939701
Change-Id: If3856fc96e808b13d83a650ccf44e15bfd21fa67

eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

I did that to avoid some bugs that can't be passed. If all of them are passed, I will merge them into the one patch"}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-03-19 11:18:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

thanks for the patch.please find comment inline.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2021-03-16 04:04:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Honestly I cannot understand the problem statement described in the commit message.
I see two following two points:

The first one is "0.1 vs 0.099999...". It is not surprising when we use flaoting-point numbers. Programmers should take into account it, so it is not a prbolem.

The second point is "infinity decimal leads a lot of memory space". Numbers in JavaScript define symbolic values for +/-Infinity, so I don't think it leads to a lot of memory space.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/Numbers_and_dates#numbers'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2021-08-17 10:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

due to long inactivity and no response from the author.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-29 09:40:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add Number.tofixed to avoid infinite decimal

Change-Id: Ie3f61294a08fb81a7fc06996322aec88065cacf9
'}, {'created': '2018-12-10 10:46:29.000000000', 'message': 'Add Number.tofixed to avoid infinite decimal



var duration = Number((data.info.finished - data.info.started) * 100.0 / full_duration).toFixed(2)

eg: when data.info.finished = 1.2, data.info.started = 1.1, the result
is not 0.1 but 0.09999999... Besides, when the full_duration can not 
divisible, the result would be a infinite decimal and it could take up
a lot of memory space.
to avoid this question, it need Number..tofixed or Math.round, however,
the result is used to compared with 0.5, so I git review this bug. 

Change-Id: Ie3f61294a08fb81a7fc06996322aec88065cacf9
'}]
commit_message:
Add Number.tofixed to avoid infinite decimal



var duration = Number((data.info.finished - data.info.started) * 100.0 / full_duration).toFixed(2)

eg: when data.info.finished = 1.2, data.info.started = 1.1, the result
is not 0.1 but 0.09999999... Besides, when the full_duration can not 
divisible, the result would be a infinite decimal and it could take up
a lot of memory space.
to avoid this question, it need Number..tofixed or Math.round, however,
the result is used to compared with 0.5, so I git review this bug. 

Change-Id: Ie3f61294a08fb81a7fc06996322aec88065cacf9

commit_message:
Add Math.round to avoid infinite decimal


when the full_duration can not divisible, the result would be a infinite
decimal and it could take up a lot of memory space.
to avoid this question, it need Math.round, so I git review this bug.


Change-Id: Ic2d1a435a823bc4190dc2221092c8597081d173b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-06 15:15:49.000000000', 'message': "Initial Network Topology AngularJS port base.

Takes the existing Network Topology (both flat and graph)
and copies it into an AngularJS panel implementation. This
commit is meant as a first in a series of changes the
end goal of which is a full reimplementation of topology
in AngularJS.

Most of the Topology code was copied wholesale, which
means any extant issues from the non-angular version
are mostly still present and will be fixed at a later
time.

One major change was the reimplementation of pop-up
balloons as (very rudimentary) AngularJS components
to resolve issues with colliding templating systems -
the Hogan template compilation has been replaced by the
Angular system.

The ng panel itself was implemented to match the reference
Images panel implementation. A new ANGULAR_FEATURES
variable, 'topology_panel', has been added to settings.py to
enable and disable the new feature.

Change-Id: I5a8f2f0df1d716aaa1210f31a334b81a1e12605b
Implements: blueprint angular-network-topology

commit_message:
Initial Network Topology AngularJS port base.

Takes the existing Network Topology (both flat and graph)
and copies it into an AngularJS panel implementation. This
commit is meant as a first in a series of changes the
end goal of which is a full reimplementation of topology
in AngularJS.

Most of the Topology code was copied wholesale, which
means any extant issues from the non-angular version
are mostly still present and will be fixed at a later
time.

One major change was the reimplementation of pop-up
balloons as (very rudimentary) AngularJS components
to resolve issues with colliding templating systems -
the Hogan template compilation has been replaced by the
Angular system.

The ng panel itself was implemented to match the reference
Images panel implementation. A new ANGULAR_FEATURES
variable, 'topology_panel', has been added to settings.py to
enable and disable the new feature.

Change-Id: I5a8f2f0df1d716aaa1210f31a334b81a1e12605b
Implements: blueprint angular-network-topology

Alright, slightly more substantial rework... but this actually now gives us A LOT of options for how we can cache things.

We can now use this to cache as normal per request, or we can cache per project and let the LRU clear the value out rather than weakrefs.

We can cache extension lists globally, and have them expire and refresh.

So yeah, I think there will be a bit of follow up that could increase performance in a few places for us but increasing the use of useful caching without causing anymore memory problems!'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-10-10 04:37:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2018-10-10 06:31:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-10-23 23:22:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-10-24 04:36:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I think this isn't too much over-engineering. The actual amount of code changes are small (mostly indentation).

The most complex bit is the key handling, which almost becomes a little cleaner, and that in particular gives us a bunch of flexibility for how we want to cache things.

We probably will want some follow up to actually add some more complex caching afterwards.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-10-30 03:34:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

In our testing we've confirmed that the other patch (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/605024/) doesn't really solve the memory problem entirely, but this patch on top of it does a good job at capping the cache.

It appears that garbage collection isn't really being triggered enough for the weakrefs to always be collected, so an explicit cache cap would work better and we can tailor the max_size and key_func in subsequent patches to further lower cache limits and use."}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2018-10-31 12:41:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-09 01:32:02.000000000', 'message': 'rework memoized as a LRU cache

memoized now operates as a LRU cache that additionally uses
weakrefs to clear keys. The max_size of the LRU cache and
whether weakrefs are used is now configurable with the memoized
decorator definition.

This will allow us to turn off weakrefs for functions that should
ideally be cached as long as possible, and use the weakrefs to clear
items quickly (such as along with a request) when appropriate.

Change-Id: Iad8a34af3637c13ae46854ebe36bc477baf020a8

commit_message:
expand memoized for more advanced caching

memoized now allows value invalidation with an optional expiry
on cached values. The expiry_time is configurable with the
decorator definition.

We can now also override the get key function with a custom one
for specific per project or other conditional caching.

Updated some API calls to use these new features.

Change-Id: Iad8a34af3637c13ae46854ebe36bc477baf020a8

commit_message:
integration tests - added chrome browser support

* all tests can run on chrome headless
* skipped test_credentials for chrome browser as sh file download is not supported

Change-Id: I3fa51d35975a46f7277423d54d9b1a7ac2a71647

This seems to be entirely removing the .dropdown-menu class; judging by the SCSS files, this is still in use, so that needs to be accounted for. Either the SCSS needs cleaning up, or we're removing functionality here.

( I know its WIP, just leaving thoughts while they are on my brain so I dont forget later :) )"}, {'account_id': 9155, 'date': '2016-11-08 22:32:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> This seems to be entirely removing the .dropdown-menu class;

This removes nested ul.drop

 > This seems to be entirely removing the .dropdown-menu class;
 > judging by the SCSS files, this is still in use, so that needs to
 > be accounted for. Either the SCSS needs cleaning up, or we're
 > removing functionality here.
 > 
 > ( I know its WIP, just leaving thoughts while they are on my brain
 > so I dont forget later :) )

Yes, but removes a nested ul.dropdown-menu inside of another ul.dropdown-menu.  The parent ul.dropdown-menu stay as it is, this helps to cycle all <li> items. (check context_selection and user_menu)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-08 23:26:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

This was put into place to enable high customization of these dropdowns.  By grouping them all together, you are preventing anything other than the very basic standard use case.

One example, in particular, is that you may want them to be horizontal instead of all grouped vertically.

This was by design.'}, {'account_id': 9155, 'date': '2016-11-22 17:22:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> This was put into place to enable high customization of these
 > dropdowns.  By grouping them all together, you are preventing
 > anything other than the very basic standard use case.
 > 
 > One example, in particular, is that you may want them to be
 > horizontal instead of all grouped vertically.
 > 
 > This was by design.

I think I've seen a case where this design was implemented for the reason you just said :), is that in the context selection menu? User menu could be OK with this change?"}, {'account_id': 9155, 'date': '2016-11-22 22:35:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-22 23:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

For now, after image created from horizon, horizon won't update the
status of this image. So I add the function to pull the status of this
image from the backend server until the status is not in transition.

Change-Id: I1f44903b9d499dc418804ed41ea03848d8a98fbe
Closes-Bug: #1645858

commit_message:
Add status update for image after creation operation

For now, after image created from horizon, horizon won't update the
status of this image. So I add the function to pull the status of this
image from the backend server until the status is not in transition.

Change-Id: I1f44903b9d499dc418804ed41ea03848d8a98fbe
Closes-Bug: #1645858

commit_message:
base/deb: bump 'system' groups limit beyond Kolla ones

Pacemaker complains that group 'haclient' already exists
during installation and is not 'system group'. So let bump
range for 'system' groups to make it happier.

Our images do not have normal groups so it should not affect.
Partial-Bug: #1934753

Change-Id: I4a79815f4e19d82fa77341672cd26d2282800f6a

commit_message:
Show "Forced Down" compute service status with --long

Currently, the unified client does not have the ability to show the
"Forced Down" field of a GET /os-services response in microversion 2.11
even though the legacy client can.

This adds a "Forced Down" column to the 'openstack compute service list
--long' command output when microversion 2.11 is used.

Story: 2009115
Task: 43011

Change-Id: I10bc2fedbf0e867a990227962b2b6e60f5681f69

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-12 07:56:49.000000000', 'message': 'Support reading Kayobe environment name from file

If using separate branches for each environment, it can be useful to
read the environment name from a file committed to each branch. Or, if
sharing the same branch for all environments, it can be useful to set
the default environment to one with lower impact, e.g. dev or staging.

If no --environment option is specified and a .environment file exists
at the root of the directory, use its content as KAYOBE_ENVIRONMENT.

Change-Id: I22b2b466e47a3b4d96931d754a4de7544f0ada5d
(cherry picked from commit 2af2c3a3b5387c577801b165ecd749fe782fddb9)
(cherry picked from commit df9ae7089959adc35935cd8b33a71ec60d94d209)
'}]
commit_message:
Support reading Kayobe environment name from file

If using separate branches for each environment, it can be useful to
read the environment name from a file committed to each branch. Or, if
sharing the same branch for all environments, it can be useful to set
the default environment to one with lower impact, e.g. dev or staging.

If no --environment option is specified and a .environment file exists
at the root of the directory, use its content as KAYOBE_ENVIRONMENT.

Change-Id: I22b2b466e47a3b4d96931d754a4de7544f0ada5d
(cherry picked from commit 2af2c3a3b5387c577801b165ecd749fe782fddb9)
(cherry picked from commit df9ae7089959adc35935cd8b33a71ec60d94d209)

We introduce support for running both the NB and SB OVN databases in
clustered mode. This OVN DBs clustered mode is based on OVNs own
clustering protocol and does not rely on pacemaker.

Clustering the two OVN databases increases reliability. The cluster
works in active-active mode and has the potential to be more
resilient and performant.

See
https://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/ref/ovsdb.7/#clustered-database-service-model
for more information.

NB: Some changes for this train backport are needed:
- firewall_rules
- go back to the old way of doing TLS (i.e. no system-roles.certificate)
- template version back to rocky
- Add 'DefaultPasswords:' parameter

commit_message:
OVN DBs clustering

We introduce support for running both the NB and SB OVN databases in
clustered mode. This OVN DBs clustered mode is based on OVNs own
clustering protocol and does not rely on pacemaker.

Clustering the two OVN databases increases reliability. The cluster
works in active-active mode and has the potential to be more
resilient and performant.

See
https://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/ref/ovsdb.7/#clustered-database-service-model
for more information.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@acksyn.org>

NB: Some changes for this train backport are needed:
- firewall_rules
- go back to the old way of doing TLS (i.e. no system-roles.certificate)
- template version back to rocky
- Add 'DefaultPasswords:' parameter
- Set tripleo_container_manage_systemd_order: false (I believe it was a
  mistake to start with)
- Include I50cf3b7d79d8cd139ae514438e147df73901a366 (fix typo in northd)

Related-Bug: #1931133
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/801654
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-tripleo/+/796149

Change-Id: I59bfe69dbb5f3d525ac6f6d655577d24036328c0
(cherry picked from commit baf4a16149d2a31ccb331cc96b89871e71c00734)

commit_message:
Fix tripleo.repos.get_hash module

- fixes import typo that prevented module_utils from importing
- avoids reading config.yaml as ansiballz does not include data files
- ensure module works (tox -e packaging)
- replace use of requests library inside ansible module

Change-Id: I86495c7da8584d5811f32178bbd985cf5f864323

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2020-11-27 18:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'm still not super happy about doing this kind of magic rewriting, but what gets me over the fence (on the "approve this" side) is that we sanitize/rewrite the hostname, not the display name. So the server name remains whatever the user gave, and the hostname is used in 2 places: 1. passed via the metadata API/config drive to cloud-init within the guest and 2. As the `OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hostname` attribute in the API, only visible to admins. That being said, -1 because: 1. what Sean said 2. Could we at least document this somewhere? That the hostname is the display name put through this meat gringer to come out all nice and pretty at the other end?'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2020-11-27 20:22:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-27 17:42:02.000000000', 'message': "utils: Sanitize purely numeric TLD in hostnames

When creating an instance, nova sanitizes the 'instance.name' attribute,
using the 'nova.utils.truncate_hostname' function, and stores this as
the 'instance.hostname' attribute. If neutron has the DNS extension
enabled then this attribute will be reported as the 'dns_name' value
when attaching ports [1].

Nova's sanitization of hostnames is good, but while it allows for FQDN,
it does not validate the TLD in these scenarios. This can be
problematic for instances with common names such as 'ubuntu18.04' or
'test.a', which aren't valid since TLDs must start with an alpha
character and must be greater than 1 character long, respectively. We
don't want to remove support for FQDN, at least not without providing an
alternative way to support this, but we also don't want errors failing
to spawn with errors like so:

  RescheduledException: Build of instance foo was re-scheduled:
  Invalid input for dns_name.
  Reason: 'test-ubuntu-20.04' not a valid PQDN or FQDN.
  Reason: TLD '04' must not be all numeric.

This will only affect users with DNS integration supported, so we don't
want to start outright rejecting these requests for everyone else. We
also don't want to wait for such late failures, nor do we want to behave
differently depending on whether this feature is enable (since that
should be transparent to users). Instead, we continue down the vein of
sanitization and replace periods with hyphens where not doing so would
result in invalid TLDs. For example:

  test-ubuntu-20.04  ->  Server-6c10508e-30d7-11eb-adc1-0242ac120002
  test.ubuntu.20.04  ->  Server-61b03c6c-30d7-11eb-adc1-0242ac120002
  test.ubuntu.20.04  ->  Server-c2a447b9-a60e-435c-a450-cc8249102270
  test-ubuntu.fossa  ->  test-ubuntu.fossa

(where the UUIDs correspond to the UUID of the instance)

This is possibly going to lead to some odd behavior, but that's an
inherent flaw with sanitization and already the case when we have
instances whose names are made up of non-alphanumeric characters. The
long-term solution to this is probably to expose a hostname attribute
for creating servers, which we can validate properly. That would allow
us to avoid all this crazy stuff, however, it would require an API
microversion and changes to peoples workflows. This is therefore
determined to be a suitable measure for now.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/victoria/admin/config-dns-int.html

Change-Id: I2fac7f919e9ddd6b0925d3e5d04e61b2ba1b8c82
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1581977
"}, {'created': '2021-01-14 11:33:39.000000000', 'message': "utils: Remove periods from instance hostnames

When creating an instance, nova sanitizes the 'instance.name' attribute,
using the 'nova.utils.sanitize_hostname' function, and stores this as
the 'instance.hostname' attribute. If neutron has the DNS extension
enabled then this attribute will be reported as the 'dns_name' value
when attaching ports [1].

Nova does not currently remove or replace periods in the name as part of
this sanitization. This results in the hostname being identified as a
(FQDN) fully qualified domain name, with all the constraints placed on
FQDNs [2]. This can be problematic for instances with common names such
as 'ubuntu18.04' or 'test.a', which aren't valid since TLDs must start
with an alpha character and must be greater than 1 character long,
respectively. Attempting to boot instances with such names can result in
failures like the below when DNS integration is enabled in neutron:

  RescheduledException: Build of instance foo was re-scheduled:
  Invalid input for dns_name.
  Reason: 'test-ubuntu-20.04' not a valid PQDN or FQDN.
  Reason: TLD '04' must not be all numeric.

Start replacing these periods with hyphens. This is a change in behavior
and may affect users who are relying on this inadvertent support for
instance names as FQDNs when using cloud-init, however, a quick poll on
openstack-discuss [3] suggests the people that are using FQDN-like
instance names are setting hostnames in the guest explicitly and not
relying on the information provided via the nova metadata service,
meaning this will not affect them.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/victoria/admin/config-dns-int.html
[2] https://stackoverflow.com/a/53875771/613428
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-November/019113.html

Change-Id: I2fac7f919e9ddd6b0925d3e5d04e61b2ba1b8c82
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1581977
"}]
commit_message:
utils: Remove periods from instance hostnames

When creating an instance, nova sanitizes the 'instance.name' attribute,
using the 'nova.utils.sanitize_hostname' function, and stores this as
the 'instance.hostname' attribute. If neutron has the DNS extension
enabled then this attribute will be reported as the 'dns_name' value
when attaching ports [1].

Nova does not currently remove or replace periods in the name as part of
this sanitization. This results in the hostname being identified as a
(FQDN) fully qualified domain name, with all the constraints placed on
FQDNs [2]. This can be problematic for instances with common names such
as 'ubuntu18.04' or 'test.a', which aren't valid since TLDs must start
with an alpha character and must be greater than 1 character long,
respectively. Attempting to boot instances with such names can result in
failures like the below when DNS integration is enabled in neutron:

  RescheduledException: Build of instance foo was re-scheduled:
  Invalid input for dns_name.
  Reason: 'test-ubuntu-20.04' not a valid PQDN or FQDN.
  Reason: TLD '04' must not be all numeric.

Start replacing these periods with hyphens. This is a change in behavior
and may affect users who are relying on this inadvertent support for
instance names as FQDNs when using cloud-init, however, a quick poll on
openstack-discuss [3] suggests the people that are using FQDN-like
instance names are setting hostnames in the guest explicitly and not
relying on the information provided via the nova metadata service,
meaning this will not affect them.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/victoria/admin/config-dns-int.html
[2] https://stackoverflow.com/a/53875771/613428
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-November/019113.html

Change-Id: I2fac7f919e9ddd6b0925d3e5d04e61b2ba1b8c82
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1581977

commit_message:
container GET: return 503 if policy index mismatches

Return a 503 to the original container listing request if a GET from a
shard returns objects from a different policy than requested (e.g. due
to the shard container server not being upgraded).

Co-Authored-By: Tim Burke <tim.burke@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ieab6238030e8c264ee90186012be6e9da937b42e

commit_message:
Enhance os-ken to support Nicira PacketIn2

neutron ovs agent has to handle advanced packet_in
with custom userdata which is necessary to openflow-based
floating IP implementation, but current os-ken doesn't
have such infrastructure.

This story is to enhance os-ken in order that neutron ovs
agent can act as an advanced SDN controller to handle
advanced packet_in.

Story: #2008964
Task: #42600
Related-Bug: #1931953

Signed-off-by: Yi Yang <yangyi01@inspur.com>

Change-Id: I4f993be5dd4a5f48396c4be152da5b61ea92392f

commit_message:
Remove devstack-gate feature list related task

devstack-gate project was deprecated [1] so there is no need to update
the feature list anymore.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-June/023180.html

Change-Id: I0b2c42b92d5d2d3767e49f40c426a430f767c46f

subject: [wallaby-only] [devstack] Fix path to dashboard policy
messages: [{'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2021-08-07 10:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 24501, 'date': '2021-08-17 06:34:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2021-08-17 06:35:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nthanks for cross-checking'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-07 10:00:49.000000000', 'message': '[wallaby-only] [devstack] Fix path to dashboard policy

In Wallaby, we merged the deprecation of JSON policy file and
moved to YAML by default.
However, dashboard has only really followed in Xena, leaving
the devstack plugin masakari dashboard policy symlink broken.
This patch fixes that.

Note we cannot easily move the dashboard policy file in Wallaby
without breaking existing (production) deployments, hence why
doing this instead of backporting.

Change-Id: Ie4687f4bfde4c29ba2805c3a6214267e3f1705e4
'}]
commit_message:
[wallaby-only] [devstack] Fix path to dashboard policy

In Wallaby, we merged the deprecation of JSON policy file and
moved to YAML by default.
However, dashboard has only really followed in Xena, leaving
the devstack plugin masakari dashboard policy symlink broken.
This patch fixes that.

Note we cannot easily move the dashboard policy file in Wallaby
without breaking existing (production) deployments, hence why
doing this instead of backporting.

Change-Id: Ie4687f4bfde4c29ba2805c3a6214267e3f1705e4

Hello, thank you for your contribution but changes of this kind need to go through a special process. They should be designed and presented to the core team which has to approve them. Please get familiar with https://docs.openstack.org/masakari/latest/user/process.html and the documentation linked there. Actually, we are now working on an alternative that may suit your use case as well (as I understand it) and it's monitoring via consul which is more flexible and avoids the situations I think you are trying to prevent here. See https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/masakari-specs/+/734017

If you want to reach out to the team, I strongly suggest using the mailing list: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/
We are also on OFTC IRC at #openstack-masakari and we even have weekly meetings there: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Masakari
I will be on PTO (vacations) the next two weeks so I will likely not respond back (and the next 2 meetings are actually cancelled) but please take this opportunity to familiarise yourself with the community and its processes."}, {'account_id': 32722, 'date': '2021-06-29 14:51:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
masakari should evaluate host status when host fails

Masakari can evaluate host status and determine whether can use force_down api. For example, if host occurs crash or is powered off, masakari can force_down api.In all, engine shoud have right to decide.

In order to achieve above, masakari should can get ipmi info、management ip, business ip and storage ip of hosts. Ipmi info can stored in masakari-monitors notification payload; Ips should stored in file or db.

Closes-Bug: #1928793
Change-Id: I6b145387233f05fdee776fc2633277a39fd887ce

commit_message:
Add support for oslo.reports library options

This change adds support for options of the olso.reports library, which
is used in several components to generate Guru Meditation Reports(GMR).

Change-Id: I2db5a2639ea98ed983a9d07e6cef1f493c6ae6b5

... and update the logic to handle neutron::service_plugins to follow
existing implementations to handle ListOpt. The updated logic allows
using a flat string which is useful when only one item is used. Also,
it is enforced the actual parameter is removed from conf file when

Change-Id: I0921a1d7012a76b9e6523715ea569f2476426d6a

commit_message:
Get rid of deprecated is_array method

... and update the logic to handle neutron::service_plugins to follow
existing implementations to handle ListOpt. The updated logic allows
using a flat string which is useful when only one item is used. Also,
it is enforced the actual parameter is removed from conf file when
the puppet parameter is set to $::os_service_default.

Closes-Bug: #1939088
Change-Id: I0921a1d7012a76b9e6523715ea569f2476426d6a

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-28 15:53:05.000000000', 'message': "WIP/DNM - Removed unused db and wal

Ceph cluster is now provisioned by cephadm using a spec
where disks and logical volumes can be defined. However
due to [1] we can't specify db and wal using a path.
The purpose of the patch is to remove the unused logical
volumes and keep the one needed to build the osd in CI.

[1] https://tracker.ceph.com/issues/46558

Change-Id: I26ae3b3a1ea9ce99d7855d6484bd42fef9360e76
"}, {'created': '2021-08-06 08:46:13.000000000', 'message': 'Removed unused db and wal

Ceph cluster is now provisioned by cephadm using a spec
where disks and logical volumes can be defined. However,
cephadm takes care about defining the disk layout if
nothing is specified.
The purpose of the patch is to remove the unused logical
volumes and keep the one needed to build the osd in CI.

Change-Id: I26ae3b3a1ea9ce99d7855d6484bd42fef9360e76

commit_message:
Removed unused db and wal

Ceph cluster is now provisioned by cephadm using a spec
where disks and logical volumes can be defined. However,
cephadm takes care about defining the disk layout if
nothing is specified.
The purpose of the patch is to remove the unused logical
volumes and keep the one needed to build the osd in CI.

Depends-On: I116a0e9d7fadca525c1e8f5328df77235379c09c
Change-Id: I26ae3b3a1ea9ce99d7855d6484bd42fef9360e76

commit_message:
Dep's should be restricted by upper-constraints

Tox trying to install latest versions for building docs which may
not be supported by stable and lower branches, so should be
restricted by respective version's upper-constraints.txt

Change-Id: I5ba34141e51186304c09d8a37250cbf88fa7b8dd

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-01 09:50:27.000000000', 'message': "remove unicode from code

In Python 3, all strings are represented in Unicode.In Python 2 are
stored internally as 8-bit ASCII, hence it is required to attach 'u'
to make it Unicode. It is no longer necessary now.

Change-Id: I66fde644d86f8ad61e9df1fd98311e0c3dc9994c
"}, {'created': '2021-03-02 01:00:48.000000000', 'message': "remove unicode from code

In Python 3, all strings are represented in Unicode.In Python 2 are
stored internally as 8-bit ASCII, hence it is required to attach 'u'
to make it Unicode. It is no longer necessary now.

Change-Id: I66fde644d86f8ad61e9df1fd98311e0c3dc9994c
"}]
commit_message:
remove unicode from code

In Python 3, all strings are represented in Unicode.In Python 2 are
stored internally as 8-bit ASCII, hence it is required to attach 'u'
to make it Unicode. It is no longer necessary now.

Change-Id: I66fde644d86f8ad61e9df1fd98311e0c3dc9994c

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-06 19:09:03.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Action module for bulk host prep

Change-Id: Ia8712a253d73609c121dd69243a3b222c6748e6d
'}, {'created': '2021-07-06 20:23:09.000000000', 'message': 'Action module for bulk host prep

In order to reduce the overall tasks that we perform, we can batch up
much of the host prep actions into an action plugin to execute them much
more efficiently than the standalone tasks.  This change creates a
tripleo_host_prep action plugin that runs through data provided via
host_prep_data.  The plugin creates groups, then users, then
directories, then files, then applies seboolean and finally applies
sefcontext.

Change-Id: Ia8712a253d73609c121dd69243a3b222c6748e6d

commit_message:
Action module for bulk host prep

In order to reduce the overall tasks that we perform, we can batch up
much of the host prep actions into an action plugin to execute them much
more efficiently than the standalone tasks.  This change creates a
tripleo_host_prep action plugin that runs through data provided via
host_prep_data.  The plugin creates groups, then users, then
directories, then files, then applies seboolean and finally applies
sefcontext.

Change-Id: Ia8712a253d73609c121dd69243a3b222c6748e6d

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead aaa

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I7ba0d837a5eca6767a2050a3ae9b9587178b65a3

commit_message:
Add a project scope read-only role to keystoneauth

This patch continues work for more of the "Consistent and
Secure Default Policies". We already have system scope
personas implemented, but the architecture people are asking
for project scope now. At least we don't need domain scope.

Change-Id: If7d39ac0dfbe991d835b76eb79ae978fc2fd3520

-1 because I think we should validate the policy index at backend otherwise looks good and a great improvement. The commit message could probably do with some cleanup given that this is independent of any policy migration changes.

Some of the suggested changes are in this follow-up, feel free to squash if you like it:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/803589'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2021-08-06 00:12:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-08-06 10:48:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-08-06 10:55:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think we ought to preserve the header when recursively listing (see follow up for squashing https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/803729):

- Sharded root container has all objects deleted

- root container is deleted and revived with new policy index

- shard ranges still have old policy

- shard range start to shard itself: this is very unlikely with autosharding because new object put in the shard will have root's policy, not shard's policy, so shard will report itself as having 0 objects to root; but with manual sharding this could happen.

- sub-shards have old policy index

- listing root will redirect to original shards, then sharding shard redirects to sub-shards"}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-08-06 15:12:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I tweaked the commit message slightly.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2021-08-09 00:56:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> 
> - sub-shards have old policy index
> 
> - listing root will redirect to original shards, then sharding shard redirects to sub-shards

I did think about this when writing the patch, (I have a note on my notepad) but then obviously promptly forgot to loop back and think about it some more. Thanks for bringing it up! .. and potentially fixing it (haven't looked at the follow up yet, will now)."}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2021-08-09 05:12:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-08-09 11:41:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-04 07:21:46.000000000', 'message': "conatiner-server: return objects of a given policy

There is a tight coupling between a root container and it's shards and
there can be a tail before a roots storage policy index is migrated to
it's shards. Especially in the case of a delete and creating the new
container again with a new policy.
When we PUT objects in to a root container, it'll redirect them, with
the roots policy to the shards. And the shards are happy to take them.
But when it comes to GETs, the root forwards the GET onto it's shards
whom currently wont respond with objects (which they probably took) becuase
they are of a different policy. When getting objects from the container
server, the policy used is always the brokers policy.

This patch corrects this behaviour by allowing the ability to override
the policy index to use. If the request to the container server
contains an 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index' header it'll be used
instead of the policy index stored in the broker. This header isn't
added between the Proxy -> Container servers by default.

This patch adds the root containers policy as this header to the proxy
container controllers `_get_from_shards` method which is used to build up
the GET response for a shard container.

On a plus side this new container policy API allows us a way to check
containers for object listing is other policies. So might come in handy
for OPs/SREs.

Change-Id: I026b699fc5f0fba619cf524093632d67ca38d32f

Change-Id: I026b699fc5f0fba619cf524093632d67ca38d32f

Change-Id: I026b699fc5f0fba619cf524093632d67ca38d32f
"}, {'created': '2021-08-12 01:52:23.000000000', 'message': "container-server: return objects of a given policy

There is a tight coupling between a root container and it's shards the
shards hold the object metadata for the root container, so are really an
extension of the root.
When we PUT objects in to a root container, it'll redirect them, with
the root's policy, to the shards. And the shards are happy to take them,
even if the shard's policy is different to the root's.
But when it comes to GETs, the root redirects the GET onto it's shards
whom currently wont respond with objects (which they probably took) because
they are of a different policy. When getting objects from the container
server, the policy used is always the brokers policy.

This patch corrects this behaviour by allowing the ability to override
the policy index to use. If the request to the container server
contains an 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index' header it'll be used
instead of the policy index stored in the broker.

This patch adds the root containers policy as this header in the proxy
container controllers `_get_from_shards` method which is used by the proxy
to redirect a GET to a root to it's shards.

Further, a new header has been added, if the container resp contains an
`X-Backend-Record-Type: object` header, then it means the response if a
response with objects in it. In this case this patch also adds a
`X-Backend-Record-Storage-Policy-Index  header so the spi of the given
objects is known, as X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index in the response
_always_ represents the spi of the container itself.

On a plus side this new container policy API allows us a way to check
containers for object listing is other policies. So might come in handy
for OPs/SREs.

Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I026b699fc5f0fba619cf524093632d67ca38d32f
"}, {'created': '2021-08-12 12:57:20.000000000', 'message': "container-server: return objects of a given policy

There is a tight coupling between a root container and its shards: the
shards hold the object metadata for the root container, so are really
an extension of the root.  When we PUT objects in to a root container,
it'll redirect them, with the root's policy, to the shards. And the
shards are happy to take them, even if the shard's policy is different
to the root's.  But when it comes to GETs, the root redirects the GET
onto it's shards whom currently wont respond with objects (which they
probably took) because they are of a different policy. Currently, when
getting objects from the container server, the policy used is always
the broker's policy.

This patch corrects this behaviour by allowing the ability to override
the policy index to use. If the request to the container server
contains an 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index' header it'll be used
instead of the policy index stored in the broker.

This patch adds the root container's policy as this header in the
proxy container controller's `_get_from_shards` method which is used
by the proxy to redirect a GET to a root to its shards.

Further, a new backend response header has been added. If the
container response contains an `X-Backend-Record-Type: object` header,
then it means the response is a response with objects in it. In this
case this patch also adds a `X-Backend-Record-Storage-Policy-Index`
header so the policy index of the given objects is known, as
X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index in the response _always_ represents the
policy index of the container itself.

On a plus side this new container policy API allows us a way to check
containers for object listing is other policies. So might come in handy
for OPs/SREs.

Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I026b699fc5f0fba619cf524093632d67ca38d32f
"}, {'created': '2021-08-16 10:35:00.000000000', 'message': "container-server: return objects of a given policy

shards are happy to take them, even if the shard's policy is different
to the root's.  But when it comes to GETs, the root redirects the GET
onto it's shards whom currently wont respond with objects (which they
probably took) because they are of a different policy. Currently, when
getting objects from the container server, the policy used is always
the broker's policy.

This patch corrects this behaviour by allowing the ability to override
the policy index to use. If the request to the container server
contains an 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index' header it'll be used
instead of the policy index stored in the broker.

This patch adds the root container's policy as this header in the
proxy container controller's `_get_from_shards` method which is used
by the proxy to redirect a GET to a root to its shards.

Further, a new backend response header has been added. If the
container response contains an `X-Backend-Record-Type: object` header,
then it means the response is a response with objects in it. In this
case this patch also adds a `X-Backend-Record-Storage-Policy-Index`
header so the policy index of the given objects is known, as
X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index in the response _always_ represents the
policy index of the container itself.

On a plus side this new container policy API allows us a way to check
containers for object listing is other policies. So might come in handy
for OPs/SREs.

Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I026b699fc5f0fba619cf524093632d67ca38d32f

commit_message:
container-server: return objects of a given policy

There is a tight coupling between a root container and its shards: the
shards hold the object metadata for the root container, so are really
an extension of the root.  When we PUT objects in to a root container,
it'll redirect them, with the root's policy, to the shards. And the
shards are happy to take them, even if the shard's policy is different
to the root's.  But when it comes to GETs, the root redirects the GET
onto it's shards whom currently wont respond with objects (which they
probably took) because they are of a different policy. Currently, when
getting objects from the container server, the policy used is always
the broker's policy.

This patch corrects this behaviour by allowing the ability to override
the policy index to use. If the request to the container server
contains an 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index' header it'll be used
instead of the policy index stored in the broker.

This patch adds the root container's policy as this header in the
proxy container controller's `_get_from_shards` method which is used
by the proxy to redirect a GET to a root to its shards.

Further, a new backend response header has been added. If the
container response contains an `X-Backend-Record-Type: object` header,
then it means the response is a response with objects in it. In this
case this patch also adds a `X-Backend-Record-Storage-Policy-Index`
header so the policy index of the given objects is known, as
X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index in the response _always_ represents the
policy index of the container itself.

On a plus side this new container policy API allows us a way to check
containers for object listing is other policies. So might come in handy
for OPs/SREs.

Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I026b699fc5f0fba619cf524093632d67ca38d32f

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-20 13:57:59.000000000', 'message': 'Make fw driver configurable

The neutron-gateway uses the firewall driver just as other nodes
do when running neutron-openvswitch-agent. It is currently
hardcoded to the deprecated iptables_hybrid driver. This patch
allows the driver to be changed to openvswitch same as with the
neutron-openvswitch driver with a firewall-driver config option
that defaults to iptables_hybrid so as to maintain backwards
compatibility.

Change-Id: I4f5482425c91b5ad556c384abba7c27137c1948f
'}]
commit_message:
Make fw driver configurable

The neutron-gateway uses the firewall driver just as other nodes
do when running neutron-openvswitch-agent. It is currently
hardcoded to the deprecated iptables_hybrid driver. This patch
allows the driver to be changed to openvswitch same as with the
neutron-openvswitch driver with a firewall-driver config option
that defaults to iptables_hybrid so as to maintain backwards
compatibility.

Change-Id: I4f5482425c91b5ad556c384abba7c27137c1948f

commit_message:
Replace upgrades template when providers run again

The upgrades template was commented out to get
a change through that fixed failing content providers.

This template can be added back when the two
relevant release content provider jobs are
passing again.

Change-Id: I4dea9a3915d21de5c81cc25b32c227cfdb26b55d

The ip functions in puppetlabs-stdlib are deprecated since 4.13.0[1]
and should be replaced.

Also, this change removes the is_ip_addresses method, because now
the method is used only with the String variables and can be replaced.

[1] https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-stdlib/commit/6d185bdaa19f698270a0df4b0a0c05618864b955

Change-Id: I28f1a718e2d24d5de6cbe40e1b1a68b1072f3f07
'}]
commit_message:
Replace deprecated ip functions

The ip functions in puppetlabs-stdlib are deprecated since 4.13.0[1]
and should be replaced.

Also, this change removes the is_ip_addresses method, because now
the method is used only with the String variables and can be replaced.

[1] https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-stdlib/commit/6d185bdaa19f698270a0df4b0a0c05618864b955

Change-Id: I28f1a718e2d24d5de6cbe40e1b1a68b1072f3f07

commit_message:
Fix --setup-only with ephemeral Heat

Commit e36e9562e3e03e078efd545ae55af175ec978cab inadvertently broke
--setup-only because the parameters for the container images were no
longer set when Heat was launched. This commit moves the ephemeral Heat
launch code to be after the paramters are defined.

Change-Id: Ied4d19af27d1e23327046857c0a849896badff52
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Update RabbitMQ probes

The current health check that is used for readiness and liveness
probes is considered intrusive and is prompt to produce false
positives[0]. The command is also deprecated and will be removed
in future version.  Updating the probes based on current
recommenation from community[1].

Ref:
[0] https://www.rabbitmq.com/monitoring.html#deprecations
[1] https://www.rabbitmq.com/monitoring.html#health-checks

Change-Id: I83750731150ff9a276f59e3c1288129581fceba5

subject: Set max_template_size for ephemeral Heat
messages:
[{'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-07-13 00:22:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2021-07-13 09:31:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't see a linked bug for this. What has changed in ephemeral heat to change this default? This is the maximum size of a single template and AFAIK has never been changed in tripleo. What's important is max_json_body_size and we already use[1] high value for it.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/src/branch/master/templates/ephemeral-heat/heat.conf.j2#L10"}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-07-14 12:05:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

>

> 
> [1] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/src/branch/master/templates/ephemeral-heat/heat.conf.j2#L10

It was something Kevin hit:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/807367/

I'm curious if it actually fixes the issue. I agree we've never set this in the past, and we should determine what has changed."}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-07-14 12:07:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I suppose technically this would not fix his issue, since the error indicates that the size would still be greater than what I've configured with this patch:

maximum allowed size (524288 bytes).

We'd have to at least use 4x the default.
Maybe it's something in his templates?"}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-07-16 15:30:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-08-16 21:42:27.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add tripleo_ovn_cluster role

We introduce support for running both the NB and SB OVN databases in
clustered mode. This OVN DBs clustered mode is based on OVN's own
clustering protocol and does not rely on pacemaker.

THT service: https://review.opendev.org/775444

Conflicts:
  zuul.d/molecule.yaml

Changes from master:
  Added molecule/default/playbook.yml

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@acksyn.org>
Change-Id: I5baa697ae351d10e53f7cf70641fe0eecede507f

subject: Fix up cluster_setup_extras usage
messages: [{'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-08-15 18:15:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2021-08-16 13:12:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-08-16 16:57:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-15 18:15:07.000000000', 'message': 'Fix up cluster_setup_extras usage

This pairs with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-tripleo/+/739933.

Starting with pcs 0.10 (CentOS/RHEL 8) the arguments to pcs cluster setup changed completely
in an incompatible way and in fact are ignored by puppet-pacemaker.

This review makes sure ${cluster_setup_extras_real} is taken into account when the cluster
is set up via pcs 0.10, addressing LP#1886789.

Related-Bug: #1886789
Change-Id: I1dc3a72a51a4f816bb79986e845798d869223ffe
'}]
commit_message:
Fix up cluster_setup_extras usage

This pairs with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-tripleo/+/739933.

Starting with pcs 0.10 (CentOS/RHEL 8) the arguments to pcs cluster setup changed completely
in an incompatible way and in fact are ignored by puppet-pacemaker.

This review makes sure ${cluster_setup_extras_real} is taken into account when the cluster
is set up via pcs 0.10, addressing LP#1886789.

Related-Bug: #1886789
Change-Id: I1dc3a72a51a4f816bb79986e845798d869223ffe

commit_message:
Allow tuning of Galera gcache size

Appropriate gcache.size values allow a cluster node to perform IST
instead of SST if the writes occurred during its downtime do not exceed
the size of the cache itself.
This is especially beneficial during maintenance windows.

Closes-Bug: #1939540

Change-Id: I483484c58ab703f3a4dcede636d733e23b051f63
(cherry picked from commit feed67dcc45eb3da818cc2ceac8cb3682a2b6364)
(cherry picked from commit 1ce9d8855db0e282a4a0c47e9afdee3f7a102c39)
(cherry picked from commit 165dcb2de05958c68e7e3ed46cd87b72c4f546fc)
(cherry picked from commit 14d6f9ae31cfa067a6c75bf28d47ca3e052c29e1)

[{'created': '2020-06-15 15:11:32.000000000', 'message': 'Update both cells

In case the shared-db relation changes after a Nova API password
update, both cells should be updated so they use the correct (new)
password. Updating only `cell1` is not sufficient as some commands,
e.g. `openstack usage list`, will access cell0 information as well.

Change-Id: I790c35a9c1c385275d8fd0008a592507c008f533
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Update both cells

In case the shared-db relation changes after a Nova API password
update, both cells should be updated so they use the correct (new)
password. Updating only `cell1` is not sufficient as some commands,
e.g. `openstack usage list`, will access cell0 information as well.

Change-Id: I790c35a9c1c385275d8fd0008a592507c008f533
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Add support for logging service plugin configuration

This patch adds possibility to configure logging's service plugin
in Neutron.
See [1] for details.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-logging.html

Change-Id: I569fa71e84582b8deb1b45dee6b619d511692b36

commit_message:
TrivialFix: Fix the filter name in config helper

The config `use_scheduler_creating_share_from_snapshot` has the
help message with wrong name of the scheduler filter that the user must
enable with the option. The filter name is `CreateFromSnapshotFilter`,
instead of `CreateShareFromSnapshot`.

Change-Id: I3e6170f8def53aabd4bc5858fa297061e2873477
(cherry picked from commit 854b1dc958db4bd903e7b3c69c242295ad1518bd)
(cherry picked from commit f1822cf40a736fcf9a7e9c849e38a97cee9d5a6a)

[{'created': '2021-07-07 21:01:07.000000000', 'message': 'Filter shares by share type "extra_specs"

This change fixes the query being used to filter share
types. We were using an "or" clause instead of an "and" clause,
and that was causing all the extra specs to be shown instead of
the ones that the user specified. With this fix, manila users will
be able to filter shares by share type extra_specs accurately.

Closes-Bug: #1929121

Change-Id: I5cf9788dcafebdf88426617d2824f4be42dbb412
(cherry picked from commit 4fbacf1df1dbe7a85726e22892d462b5b7c4e316)
(cherry picked from commit 59a0c147df9e9255b3199fbb6846311f0fe8cef1)
'}]
commit_message:
Filter shares by share type "extra_specs"

This change fixes the query being used to filter share
types. We were using an "or" clause instead of an "and" clause,
and that was causing all the extra specs to be shown instead of
the ones that the user specified. With this fix, manila users will
be able to filter shares by share type extra_specs accurately.

Closes-Bug: #1929121

Change-Id: I5cf9788dcafebdf88426617d2824f4be42dbb412
(cherry picked from commit 4fbacf1df1dbe7a85726e22892d462b5b7c4e316)
(cherry picked from commit 59a0c147df9e9255b3199fbb6846311f0fe8cef1)

[{'created': '2021-08-16 13:43:43.000000000', 'message': 'Do not install libvirt python bindings from pip

Since [1] was merged, devstack no longer installs libvirt python
bindings from pip but use distro packages. This change removes
the logic to install the python bindings using pip to follow that
change in devstack, otherwise installation fails because of conflict
between packages available in pip and one installed by distro packages.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/798514

Resolved conflicts caused by f57a51e43ca7a8903763cc24b1c510fa50a16b2c
which is not backported to stable branches.

Closes-Bug: #1939990
Related-Bug: #1933096
Change-Id: I369a95cf30e91738d10ad2e5a3d5f6988bdd76cb
(cherry picked from commit 9366bc8f18a07695aa1af9217307b0a55376a331)
(cherry picked from commit 1b97560c97d8b06ca5568b909ae69eb07d0415fc)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not install libvirt python bindings from pip

Since [1] was merged, devstack no longer installs libvirt python
bindings from pip but use distro packages. This change removes
the logic to install the python bindings using pip to follow that
change in devstack, otherwise installation fails because of conflict
between packages available in pip and one installed by distro packages.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/798514

Conflicts:
	devstack/plugin.sh

Resolved conflicts caused by f57a51e43ca7a8903763cc24b1c510fa50a16b2c
which is not backported to stable branches.

Closes-Bug: #1939990
Related-Bug: #1933096
Change-Id: I369a95cf30e91738d10ad2e5a3d5f6988bdd76cb
(cherry picked from commit 9366bc8f18a07695aa1af9217307b0a55376a331)
